pages.text: Nigersaurus taqueti comes from the Early Cretaceous, with fossils being found in the Elrhaz Formation, Niger. It is a small rebbachisauriid, growing up to 9 m in length, and weighing up to 4000 kg. Nigersaurus was surprisingly small for a sauropod of this time, and also had a very specialised skull used for feeding, with thin bones and a short but wide down-turned muzzle,

with hundreds of teeth all concentrated at the very front of the snout. Furthermore, instead of each tooth growing from its own individual socket, all the teeth grew out of a single, fused 'trough' opening, one in the upper and lower jaws respectively. The generic name derives from the place name 'Niger', the country the fossils were found in; and the Greek word 'sauros',
to mean 'reptile'. The specific name derives from the Latinsied surname of Philippe Taquet, a French palaeontologist that discovered the first fossils.
